facts.text: Petition No. 22 of 1955 filed in Original Jurisdiction under Article 32 of the Constitution for a writ in the nature of habeas corpus.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 22 of 1955. Under Article 32 of the Constitution for a Writ in the nature of habeas companypus. Sadhan Chandra Gupta  The Petitioner also present  for the petitioner.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by BOSE J. on February 23, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: 1955. February 23. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by BOSE J.-The petitioner, Hans Muller, who is number a citizen of India, and who is said to be a West German subject, was arrested by the Calcutta Police on the 18th September, 1954

facts.text: Petitioner Hans Muller is not a citizen of India and is said to be a West German subject.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, Hans Muller, who is number a citizen of India, and who is said to be a West German subject, was arrested by the Calcutta Police on the 18th September, 1954 and was placed under preventive detention.

facts.text: Hans Muller was arrested by the Calcutta Police on 18th September 1954.

anchor.surface_text: who is said to be a West German subject, was arrested by the Calcutta Police on the 18th September, 1954 and was placed under preventive detention. The order was made by the West Bengal Government under section 3 1  of the Preventive Detention Act of 1950

facts.text: Hans Muller was placed under preventive detention by the West Bengal Government under section 3(1) of the Preventive Detention Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: was arrested by the Calcutta Police on the 18th September, 1954 and was placed under preventive detention. The order was made by the West Bengal Government under section 3 1  of the Preventive Detention Act of 1950  Act IV of 1950  on the ground that his detention was with a view to making arrangements for his explusion from India.

facts.text: Grounds of detention served on Hans Muller on 22nd September 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The grounds were served on the 22nd of September, 1954. The second ground runs- That you are a foreigner within the meaning of the Foreigners Act, 1946  Act XXXI of 1946  and that it has become necessary to make arrangements for your expulsion from India

facts.text: Hans Muller wrote to the Consul-General of West Germany at Calcutta on 19th September 1954 asking for an early interview.

anchor.surface_text: On the day after his arrest, namely on the 19th of September, 1954 he wrote to the Consul-General of West Germany at Calcutta saying that be had been arrested and- asking for an early interview. This was granted.

facts.text: Interview with Consul-General granted to Hans Muller.

anchor.surface_text: asking for an early interview. This was granted. On the 21st of September 1954, the petitioner wrote to the West Bengal Government asking it to be kind enough to pass an order for our immediate repatriation from India 1287

facts.text: Hans Muller wrote to West Bengal Government on 21st September 1954 asking for immediate repatriation.

anchor.surface_text: This was granted. On the 21st of September 1954, the petitioner wrote to the West Bengal Government asking it to be kind enough to pass an order for our immediate repatriation from India 1287 and to do the necessary arrangement for our transmission out of India.

facts.text: Calcutta Police handed Hans Muller's passport to West German Consul on 9th October 1954 at Consul's request.

anchor.surface_text: On the 9th of October 1954 the Calcutta Police handed the petitioners passport over to the West German Consul at the Consuls request. This passport was issued to the petitioner by the West German Government at Nurenburg in West Germany on the 27th of November 1953.

facts.text: Passport issued to Hans Muller by West German Government at Nuremberg on 27th November 1953.

anchor.surface_text: the Calcutta Police handed the petitioners passport over to the West German Consul at the Consuls request. This passport was issued to the petitioner by the West German Government at Nurenburg in West Germany on the 27th of November 1953.

facts.text: West German Consul made entry on passport: Valid only for the return voyage to the Federal Republic of Germany until 8th January 1955.

anchor.surface_text: When the West German Consul got the passport he made the following entry on it Valid only for the return voyage to the Federal Republic of Germany until the 8th January 1955. The petitioner companyplains that this invalidated all the other visas

facts.text: Hans Muller complains that the Consul's entry invalidated all other visas and he has no passport.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner companyplains that this invalidated all the other visas and as, according to this fresh entry, the passport ceased to be valid after the 8th of January 1955, he number has numberpassport.

facts.text: West German Government wrote to West Bengal Government on 9th October 1954 about warrant of arrest against Hans Muller for frauds, proceedings pending.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day, the 9th of October 1954, the West German Government wrote to the West Bengal Government saying that a warrant of arrest was issued against the petitioner in West Germany in companynection with a number of frauds and that legal proceedings in companynection with those warrants are still pending.

facts.text: Similar charges against Hans Muller in Lebanon and Egypt as per West German Consul.

anchor.surface_text: The Consul also said that he had received information that similar charges had been made against the petitioner in Lebanon and in Egypt and be companycluded- The Government of the Federal Republic of Germany will apply for Mullers extradition

facts.text: West German Consulate requested West Bengal Government to issue provisional warrant for detention of Hans Muller till extradition.

anchor.surface_text: hereby request the Government of West Bengal to issue a provisional warrant of arrest which ensures Mullers detention up to the date of his extradition to Germany. This Consulate has already arranged for Mullers repatriation by the German boat KANDELFELS

facts.text: Repatriation of Hans Muller arranged by German boat KANDELfels arriving Calcutta on 19th October 1954, expenses borne by FRG.

anchor.surface_text: This Consulate has already arranged for Mullers repatriation by the German boat KANDELFELS due to arrive in Calcutta on the 19th instant. All 1288 expenses in companynection with Mullers repatriation will be borne by the Government of the Federal Republic of Germany.

facts.text: Secretary to West Bengal Government noted no objection to detaining Muller till 19th instant and release when boat ready.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of this letter the Secretary to the Government of West Bengal recorded the following numbere I suppose there would be numberobjection to our keeping Muller in detention till the 19th instant. We must issue order of his release as soon as his boat is ready to sail.

facts.text: West Bengal Government had no power to deport petitioner, only Central Government could.

anchor.surface_text: The West Bengal Government had numberpower to deport the petitioner. Only the Central Government companyld do that, and up till the 20th of October the Central Government had number passed any orders.

facts.text: No orders for expulsion from India issued till decision of this petition, though made and signed but held in abeyance.

anchor.surface_text: numberorders have yet been issued for his expulsion from India though we are told by the learned Attorney-General that they have been made and signed but are being held in abeyance pending the decision of this petition.

facts.text: Petitioner applied to High Court of Calcutta for habeas corpus under section 491 CrPC on 20th October 1954.

anchor.surface_text: On that date the petitioner applied to the High Court of Calcutta for a writ in the nature of habeas companypus under section 491 of the Criminal Procedure Code.

facts.text: High Court of Calcutta dismissed the petition on 10-12-1954.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court decided against the petitioner on all points and dismissed the petition on 10-12-1954. He thereupon made the present petition to this Court on the same grounds, presumably under article 32 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Present petition to Supreme Court filed on 10-1-1955 under Article 32.

anchor.surface_text: He thereupon made the present petition to this Court on the same grounds, presumably under article 32 of the Constitution. It was filed oil 10-1-1955. 1289 We will first companysider the vires of section 3 1   b .

facts.text: Petitioner contended that detention was invalid because section 3(1)(b) PDA is ultra vires Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner companytended that his detention was invalid for the following, among other, reasons Because section 3 1  b  of the Preventive Detention Act, the section under which the order was. made, is ultra vires the Constitution on three grounds-

facts.text: Detention order made by State Government under section 3(1)(b) PDA.

anchor.surface_text: The detention order is by a State Government and number by the Centre. The portion of the section on which the order is based is the part that gives a State Government power to make an order of detention against a foreigner

facts.text: West German Consul requested detention till 19th October 1954 for repatriation.

anchor.surface_text: the Secretary of the West Bengal Government recorded a numbere saying that he supposed there would be numberobjection to the West Bengal Government keeping the petitioner in detention till the 19th.

facts.text: Court holds section 3(1)(b) PDA intra vires.

anchor.surface_text: We hold that the impugned portions of section 3 1  b  of the Preventive Detention Act and section 3 2  c  of the Foreigners Act, 1946 are intra vires.

holdings.text: The legislative competence of Parliament to deal with preventive detention of foreigners under section 3(1)(b) of the Preventive Detention Act is clear, derived from Entry 9 read with Entry 10 of the Union List.

anchor.surface_text: The competence of the Central Legislature to enact a law dealing with this aspect of preventive detention is derived from Entry 9 of the Union List read with Entry 10, The portion of Entry 9 which concerns us is as follows Preventive detention for reasons connected with Foreign Affairs The scope of the expression Foreign Affairs is indicated in Entry 10 Foreign Affairs all matters which bring the Union into relation with any foreign country.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Language of entries given widest scope as settled; deals with foreign relations via expulsion and detention of foreigners.

holdings.text: The limitations imposed on preventive detention power by Articles 21 and 22 of the Constitution have been observed in section 3(1)(b) of the Preventive Detention Act.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the limitations imposed on this power by articles 21 and 22 have been observed. Article 21 guarantees the protection of personal liberty to citizen and foreigner alike. No person can be deprived of his personal liberty except according to procedure established by law, and article 22 prescribes the minimum that the procedure established by law must provide.

holdings.reasoning_summary: PDA incorporates Art.22 safeguards; aligns pre-Constitution Foreigners Act powers with constitutional procedure.

holdings.text: Section 3(1)(b) of the Preventive Detention Act is a law of preventive detention within Article 22(3).

anchor.surface_text: If no choice had been left to the Government, the position would have been different but as Government is given the right to choose, no question of want of good faith can arise merely because it exercises the right of choice which the law confers.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Law gives choice; exercising it not mala fide.

anchor.surface_text: The competence of the Central Legislature to enact a law dealing with this aspect of preventive detention is derived from Entry 9 of the Union List read with Entry 10, The portion of Entry 9 which concerns us is as follows Preventive detention for reasons connected with Foreign Affairs The scope of the expression Foreign Affairs is indicated in Entry 10 Foreign Affairs all matters which bring the Union into relation with any foreign country.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether the limitations imposed on this power by articles 21 and 22 have been observed. Article 21 guarantees the protection of personal liberty to citizen and foreigner alike. No person can be deprived of his personal liberty except according to procedure established by law, and article 22 prescribes the minimum that the procedure established by law must provide.
